Sell 1 $165 strike price call at $0.69. Buy 1 $170 strike price call at $0.2. Increase in stock price is more optimal for this position. Note that these recommendations assume that all options are European style options with no early exercise, and that the investor is trying to maximize returns from buying and selling options. The specific strategy selected will depend on the investor's overall objective, including the level of risk they are willing to take, as well as their expectations regarding the likely direction of the stock's price movement over the relevant time period. In this case, the investor seems to be engaging in a bear put spread, which is generally considered a bullish strategy because it yields a net credit, which is kept whether the stock price increases or remains above the sold put. But, since the sold call is out-of-the-money, the maximum possible loss will be restricted as the stock can only go up more than 170 - 165 or $5.

Sell 1 $133 strike price put at $0.31. Buy 1 $130 strike price put at $0.23. Decrease in stock price is more optimal for this position. This investor is implementing a bear put spread, which is generally considered a bearish strategy because the investor receives a premium for selling a put option with a higher strike price than the put option they buy, which increases as the stock price declines, resulting in a loss that is limited to the width of the spread minus the net credit received. However, since the sold strike price of 133 is above the current stock price of $131.32, the investor is expecting that the stock price will not decline more than 2 points.

data.sampled:
The name of the option strategy being implemented here is a Bull Put Spread, also known as a Long Put Spread.

The investor is simultaneously selling a put option contract with a strike price of $143 and buying two put option contracts: one with a strike price of $130 and another with a strike price of $167.5. The investor is also selling one call option contract with a strike price of $167.5 while buying another call option contract with a strike price of $175.
This strategy is considered bullish as the investor expects the stock prices to increase over a specified period. This strategy limits potential losses by selling one put option at a higher price and buying two put options at lower prices. Meanwhile, the investor benefits from selling a call option at a higher price while buying another call option at a lower price.

data.sampled:
The option strategy being implemented is a vertical spread, specifically a bull put spread. It involves selling and buying puts and calls with different strike prices but the same expiration date, thus creating a net credit.
The investor is selling a higher-premium $80 strike price put and buying a lower-premium $78 strike price put, while simultaneously shorting a higher-premium $83 strike price call and purchasing a lower-premium $85 strike price call, thus earning a credit and neutralizing the net credit from the option sales.
This strategy limits the potential gain to the difference between the premiums received for the put and call sold and the premiums paid for the put and call purchased, but it also limits the potential loss to the difference between the strike prices minus the credit received. This can be a good strategy when the investor expects the underlying stock to remain relatively stable between the short put strike and short call strike price at expiration.
